elements.2211.03052_93b2c2c086a9b36439d96f4b392ab: Consider a finite sample from an unknown distribution over a countable alphabet
elements.2211.03052_d12ccd824dd5e9873fbe30f10a2c9: Unobserved events are alphabet symbols which do not appear in the sample
elements.2211.03052_f95adaa4aedf56280ed4606ba9349: Estimating the probabilities of unobserved events is a basic problem in statistics and related fields, which was extensively studied in the context of point estimation
elements.2211.03052_d126bcc817c0c196c02031519c2ea: In this work we introduce a novel interval estimation scheme for unobserved events
elements.2211.03052_283508bc13ad59bfae569a4fb6703: Our proposed framework applies selective inference, as we construct confidence intervals (CIs) for the desired set of parameters
elements.2211.03052_195bb7dd479bca783c0de18d409b0: Interestingly, we show that obtained CIs are dimension-free, as they do not grow with the alphabet size
elements.2211.03052_821c9ed9bc480049b5621d81b2b9f: Further, we show that these CIs are (almost) tight, in the sense that they cannot be further improved without violating the prescribed coverage rate
elements.2211.03052_b9a4ff1074a06363455019fe013d8: We demonstrate the performance of our proposed scheme in synthetic and real-world experiments, showing a significant improvement over the alternatives
elements.2211.03052_bc49764e0ced048af5afb54455180: Finally, we apply our proposed scheme to large alphabet modeling
elements.2211.03052_dc38d5b5b2640cf37256bbfb3dacd: We introduce a novel simultaneous CI scheme for large alphabet distributions which outperforms currently known methods while maintaining the prescribed coverage rate.

elements.2211.03052_239dc98738b97232737ded3ed0546: Inference and estimation of unseen events is a corner-stone of large alphabet probability modeling
elements.2211.03052_c7f27b5a6aba122e3bd67f37d1e7f: Here, the goal is to address not only the unobserved events, but the entire (very) large collection of possible outcomes
elements.2211.03052_43e1ffec1bc84d755f0d9b7803558: Specifically, the large alphabet regime considers multinomial distributions in cases where
elements.2211.03052_127ebecad369a15295857a5f0e34f: This problem too is highly important to data-driven science and engineering
elements.2211.03052_7f701b916cdf6696eb86d2a422061: Its applications span a variety of disciplines including information retrieval
elements.2211.03052_5d166b47d6beab9d8079856b03434: In this section we demonstrate the favorable properties of our proposed CI, as we apply it to large alphabet inference
elements.2211.03052_a702374982e7882cb2ef94eac3b17: There exists a large body of work on point estimation of large alphabet distributions
elements.2211.03052_caf10168f6bc91383868a1cbe1c4a: The GT probability estimator (based on the GT scheme described above) is perhaps the most popular estimator for this important task
elements.2211.03052_c753617091fe5f53a672731ad5a12: While the GT estimator performs well in general, it is known to be sub-optimal for outcomes that frequently appear
elements.2211.03052_0f945657a3ee217bedd9a2319eaa7: Consequently, several modifications have been proposed, including the Jelinek-Mercer, Katz, Witten-Bell and Kneser-Ney estimators
elements.2211.03052_5c5074ae791d3df42809f7872c05a: In language modeling for example, GT is usually used to estimate the probability of infrequent words, whereas the probability of frequent words is estimated by their empirical frequency
elements.2211.03052_29829707a85a26aa0b0bfcc15accd: Different properties of the GT probability estimator were extensively studied over the years
elements.2211.03052_aaf7379c8019dd91fcb5108c1564b: Despite this broad body of work, large alphabet inference has not received much attention
elements.2211.03052_c6bffd72eccfda84480dd1a31199a: Current methods focus on two basic setups
elements.2211.03052_c32d5bdc15dfec3abd444d13419bb: The first considers an asymptotic regime, where
elements.2211.03052_7401dac5067da3a81650d64e77583: The second line of work addresses a fixed
elements.2211.03052_8afd612e2bd2528f9b37f7e4b4dba: Here, the most popular SCI scheme is arguably of Sison and Glaz
elements.2211.03052_fe0ce4e066f604c25b3634dd0543f: In their work, Sison and Glaz (SG) proposed a method which utilizes Edgeworth expansions to approximate the desired distribution
elements.2211.03052_9a4d97932d40dfb5791f65045f035: Through extensive simulations, they showed that their method leads to smaller SCIs while maintaining a coverage rate closer to the desired level, compared to known methods at the time
elements.2211.03052_702c8bbd335e81510fb21d96b47b8: Unfortunately, the SG scheme does not perform well in cases where the expected symbol counts are disparate
elements.2211.03052_8017e2809c94773d9cbfb574a23bb: introduced a bootstrap framework for the case where both
elements.2211.03052_421935a4329ff3ee2c5121a3c0852: Yet, this approach is based on bootstrap sampling and does not provide solid theoretical guarantees
elements.2211.03052_c1df2e39bbc31cbb74d58b5972879: To the best of our knowledge, no method directly addresses the large alphabet regime, with provable performance guarantees.

elements.2211.03052_dbd5dfebadd8c1ba74189be3fd70e: Typically, the performance of a CR is measured by its expected volume
elements.2211.03052_8e90899b69221bed16b96a581a9b8: That is, given two CRs, we say the one outperforms the other if its expected volume is smaller, while maintaining the prescribed confidence level
elements.2211.03052_f53f23f736f67192e3bb98cae721d: However, notice that in the large alphabet regime, the volume of a CR rapidly decays with the alphabet size

elements.2211.03052_cef872d4e391e9608e8895a169293: for each of its parameters demonstrates an exponential decay,
elements.2211.03052_e928c489b2a83ef776bc082cc295e: Therefore, we focus on the log of the volume in this regime
elements.2211.03052_5a96b33cc1f3e3353a52252a294b9: Specifically, in each of our following experiments we measure the average log volume, as we cannot directly assess the volume by numerical means
elements.2211.03052_997a2892859742b92c51266873955: Further, for the same reasons, we focus on the expected log volume as our analytical figure of merit.

elements.2211.03052_ccbfbecbafb8ec600e07d638624a3: In this work we introduce an interval estimation framework for the probability of symbols that do not appear in the sample

elements.2211.03052_815bd970d72336f71db97ef4f646e: We compare our proposed scheme to currently known methods, showing significant improvement in synthetic and real-world experiments
